definitions: travel on or operate a two-wheeled motor vehicle designed for personal transportation
examples: They motorbiked through the winding mountain roads yesterday
She loves to motorbike along the coastal highway

definitions: travel across water in a boat powered by an engine or motor
examples: We motorboated across the lake to reach the island
They often motorboat to their favorite fishing spots

definitions: travel on or operate a two-wheeled motor vehicle typically larger than a motorbike
examples: He motorcycles to work every day during summer
They motorcycled across the entire country last year

definitions: shape a soft or plastic substance into a particular form using hands or container
develop or cause to develop a fungal growth on organic matter
influence the formation or development of someone's character or abilities
examples: She carefully moulded the clay into a beautiful vase
The artist moulds bronze sculptures in his workshop
The bread had moulded in the humid pantry
Cheese moulds naturally during the aging process
His experiences in the military moulded his leadership style
Parents help mould their children's values and beliefs

definitions: slowly decay or crumble into dust through natural decomposition over time
examples: The old books mouldered away in the abandoned library
Ancient ruins moulder beneath centuries of vegetation

definitions: shed old feathers, hair, or skin to make way for new growth in animals
examples: Birds moult their feathers twice a year typically
The snake moulted its skin in the terrarium yesterday

definitions: pile or heap something up into a raised mass or small hill
examples: She mounded the mashed potatoes on each dinner plate
Workers mounded dirt around the base of the tree

definitions: get up on or climb onto something, especially a horse or vehicle
grow larger or more numerous gradually over a period of time
fix or attach something firmly in a support, frame, or setting
organize and launch a campaign, attack, or other planned activity
examples: The knight mounted his horse before the battle began
She carefully mounted the stairs to the attic
Pressure continues to mount as the deadline approaches rapidly
The debts mounted steadily throughout the economic crisis
They mounted the television securely on the bedroom wall
The museum mounted the paintings in gilded frames
The opposition mounted a fierce campaign against the proposal
Rebels mounted an attack on the government stronghold

definitions: climb mountains as a sport or profession, especially challenging or high peaks
examples: She mountaineers in the Himalayas every summer season
They have mountaineered on six of the seven continents

definitions: feel or show deep sorrow or regret for someone who has died
examples: The entire nation mourned the loss of their beloved leader
She still mourns her husband who died five years ago

definitions: hunt for or catch mice, typically done by cats or other predators
navigate or control a computer interface using a hand-operated pointing device
examples: The cat moused in the barn throughout the night
Farm cats mouse to help control the rodent population
She quickly moused over the link to open it
He moused through the document looking for errors

definitions: apply a light foamy preparation to hair for styling and holding
examples: She moussed her hair before using the blow dryer
The stylist moussed his curls to enhance their definition

definitions: move the lips as if speaking but without making any sound
say something in an insincere or unconvincing way without real meaning
examples: She mouthed 'thank you' across the crowded room silently
The student mouthed the words while reading to herself
Politicians often mouth promises they never intend to keep
He just mouths the company values without believing them

definitions: go from one place or position to another or cause something to do so
change one's place of residence or work to a different location
cause someone to have strong feelings, especially of sympathy or sadness
formally propose something in a meeting or court for consideration
examples: Please move your chair closer to the table now
The train moved slowly through the mountain tunnel
They moved to Seattle for better job opportunities
We're moving house next month after selling this one
The film's ending moved everyone in the audience to tears
His passionate speech moved even the harshest critics
I move that we adjourn the meeting until tomorrow
The senator moved to table the controversial amendment

definitions: cut grass or other plants with a machine or blade to maintain even height
examples: He mows the lawn every Saturday morning without fail
The groundskeeper mowed the football field before the game

definitions: remove dirt and manure from animal living areas or stables
spoil or ruin something through clumsy or incompetent handling
examples: She mucks out the horse stables every morning
Farm workers muck the barn twice a week
Don't muck up the presentation with unnecessary details
He completely mucked the whole project through carelessness

definitions: cover or coat something with wet soil or earth mixed with water
examples: The children mudded their clothes while playing outside
Workers mudded the walls before applying the final paint

definitions: bring into a disordered or confusing state by mixing things up
cope or carry on in a confused or inefficient way
examples: Don't muddle the files or we'll never find anything
The conflicting instructions muddled everyone in the team
We somehow muddled through despite the lack of planning
She muddled along without proper training or guidance

definitions: make something dirty or covered with mud or wet soil
make something less clear or more confusing than it was before
examples: The dog muddied the clean kitchen floor with its paws
Rain had muddied all the hiking trails
These new regulations only muddy the situation further
Don't muddy the waters with irrelevant arguments

definitions: handle something clumsily or badly, especially failing to catch or hold
examples: The goalkeeper muffed an easy save in the final minute
She muffed her lines during the crucial scene

definitions: attack and rob someone in a public place using violence or threats
examples: Three teenagers mugged an elderly man near the park
She was mugged while walking home from work yesterday

definitions: spread a protective covering of organic material over soil around plants
examples: They mulched the flower beds to retain moisture
Gardeners mulch around trees to prevent weed growth

definitions: think about something deeply and at length, considering various aspects
warm and flavor wine, cider, or beer with spices and sugar
examples: She mulled over the job offer for several days
He's still mulling whether to accept the promotion
They mulled wine with cinnamon for the winter party
We mulled cider on the stove during the holidays

definitions: obtain the product of one number by another through mathematical calculation
increase rapidly in number or quantity through reproduction or growth
examples: Students learn to multiply large numbers in fourth grade
If you multiply six by seven you get forty-two
Bacteria multiply quickly in warm, moist conditions
Problems seem to multiply when you ignore them

definitions: eat something steadily with a regular, often noisy chewing action
examples: The rabbit munched carrots in its cage all afternoon
Children munched popcorn while watching the movie

definitions: unlawfully kill another human being with premeditation and deliberate intent
examples: The defendant was accused of murdering his business partner
Someone murdered the witness before the trial began

definitions: say something in a low, soft, or indistinct voice
make a low continuous sound like that of water flowing gently
examples: She murmured words of comfort to the frightened child
He murmured something that nobody could quite hear
The stream murmured pleasantly through the peaceful valley
Voices murmured in the hallway outside the door

definitions: move or force one's way somewhere using physical strength or power
examples: He muscled his way through the crowded concert venue
The company muscled into the competitive technology market

definitions: think about something in a careful, slow, and reflective way
examples: She mused about what her life might have been
The philosopher mused on the nature of existence

definitions: travel across snow with a dogsled, especially as a command to dogs
examples: They mushed across the frozen tundra for three days
The team mushed through blizzard conditions to reach camp

definitions: increase, spread, or develop rapidly in size, number, or intensity
examples: The small town mushroomed into a major city
Costs mushroomed beyond what anyone had anticipated

definitions: collect or gather together people, things, or abstract qualities like courage
examples: The general mustered his troops for the morning inspection
She couldn't muster the energy to go out

definitions: undergo or cause to undergo change in genetic structure resulting in variant forms
examples: The virus mutated into a more dangerous strain
Scientists mutated the bacteria to study drug resistance

definitions: deaden, muffle, or eliminate the sound of something, especially electronic devices
examples: Please mute your microphone during the online presentation
She muted the television to answer the phone

definitions: rebel or revolt against constituted authority, especially by soldiers or sailors
examples: The crew mutinied against the captain's harsh treatment
Soldiers mutinied when their pay was withheld

definitions: say something in a low voice that is difficult to hear, often complaining
examples: He muttered complaints under his breath all morning
She muttered something about being treated unfairly

definitions: prevent from speaking freely or put a guard over an animal's mouth
examples: The government tried to muzzle the press before elections
They muzzled the aggressive dog during the veterinary visit

definitions: catch or arrest someone, especially suddenly or after pursuit
examples: Police nabbed the suspect after a lengthy investigation
Security guards nabbed the shoplifter at the store exit

definitions: harass someone with persistent fault-finding, complaints, or demands
examples: She nagged him constantly about his messy habits
Stop nagging me about cleaning my room

definitions: fasten or attach something using nails hammered through materials
perform or complete something perfectly or with great success
examples: They nailed the boards together to build a fence
Workers nailed shingles to the roof all afternoon
She absolutely nailed her audition for the lead role
The team nailed the presentation to the investors

definitions: give a name or title to someone or something
identify or mention someone or something by their name
appoint someone to a particular position or role officially
examples: They named their daughter after her grandmother
The company named the new product after its inventor
Can you name all the state capitals correctly?
The witness named three suspects in the robbery
The board named her as the new chief executive
He was named ambassador to France last month

definitions: sleep for a short period during the day, usually not in bed
examples: The baby naps for two hours every afternoon
He napped on the couch after lunch

definitions: provide a spoken or written account of events, especially as commentary
examples: She narrated the documentary about ocean conservation efforts
The author narrated his own audiobook with great expression

definitions: make or become less wide in physical dimension
reduce the range, extent, or number of possibilities or choices
examples: The road narrows dangerously at the mountain pass
They narrowed the doorway during the renovation
Police have narrowed their search to three suspects
We need to narrow our focus to core objectives

definitions: transfer ownership of a private industry or property to government control
examples: The government nationalized the country's oil industry last year
Several banks were nationalized during the financial crisis

definitions: plan and direct the route or course of a journey or voyage
sail or steer a ship, aircraft, or other vehicle through a planned route
examples: She navigated through the busy city streets with ease
Can you navigate while I drive the car?
The captain navigated the ship through dangerous waters
Pilots navigate using sophisticated instruments and charts

definitions: make something necessary as a result or consequence of particular circumstances
examples: The storm damage necessitated immediate repairs to the roof
Budget cuts necessitated laying off several employees

definitions: kiss and caress amorously, especially in a secluded place
examples: The teenagers were necking in the back of the theater
Couples necked on benches throughout the park

definitions: require something because it is essential or very important for a purpose
examples: Children need proper nutrition to grow and develop healthily
This project needs your immediate attention and approval

definitions: deliberately provoke or annoy someone with persistent criticism or teasing
examples: Stop needling your brother about his failed driving test
She needled him constantly about his poor fashion choices
